text:
Welcome to How To Cook That I am Ann Reardon
And today we are making the craziest cakes
you've ever seen.

When they spin they appear like things on
it are actually animated and moving.

I've done one space invaders themed cake - this
was the first computer game I ever played.

And one brightly coloured disco cake covered
in moving candy.
To make you're very own you'll need
two cakes.

I'll put all the recipe info on the howtocookthat.net
website and there's is a link in the description
below.

I am using my fluffy sponge cake recipe baked
in two 22cm tins and white chocolate ganache
frosting.

Once the cakes are cooled cut each one into
two layers.

Grab a cake board and make a hole in the centre
you'll need this later so make sure you do
that.

Add a small amount of white chocolate ganache
this stops the cakes from slipping.
And add your first layer of cake.

Pipe a circle of ganache around the edge of
the cake and this is making a border so it

keeps everything else in the middle of the
cake cake.

Zigzag some whipped cream across the middle,
just like you're colouring it in.

Then add a generous amount of fresh berries
all over the top.

Place the next layer of cake on top of that
and then repeat that with the remaining layers.

Place the rest of your ganache into a piping
bag fitted with a large flat nozzle and pipe
it around the cake to cover the whole thing.

Then use your spatula to smooth off the excess
and then place the cake into the fridge.
While that is chilling we'll make the topper.

Spread out some tempered chocolate or you
could use compound chocolate here.

Make it so it's a little bigger than your
circle.

Then shake the edge of the baking paper up
and down to smooth off the top and get rid
of any air bubbles.

Once it is starting to set add in two cake
pop sticks, pushing them down, but don't push

them all the way to the bottom because we
don't want to see them.

Then spread more chocolate over the top to
hide them.

Slide the whole thing onto a cutting board
and gently tap it on the bench to smooth out
the tops again.

Once it is nearly firm place a small bowl
on top and trace around it using a knife.

Then remove all the excess chocolate from
around the edge.

For our alien invader, place some compound
white chocolate into a bag and pipe around
the design onto some baking paper.

Try and make the edges as straight as you
can so they look like pixels.

But don't worry if it is not perfect, once
it is setting you can use a knife just to

neaten them up and cut across them if you've
gone a little over.

Once it is set add some more chocolate to
the back and stick it to the circle making
sure it is straight.

If you have any little air bubbles like I
do just add some more chocolate and immediately

smooth off with a knife to make it all look
neat.

Flip it over and add the other one making
sure you position those top pixels at the
same height.

So as it spins it will look like he is changing
positions with his little arms going up and
down.

Once the cake has been chilled check that
your sides are straight.

And because this cake will be spinning it
needs to be right or you are going to see
it if it is not straight.

If it is not quite right just add more ganache
fix it up and put it back in the fridge to
firm up.

Place some black fondant over the top of the
cake.

Then use scissors to cut off the overhang
so it is not getting weighed down, it's not
pulling it down.

Then you want to cut off right up to the edge
of the cake so you are left with a neat circle
like a disc sitting on top of the cake.

Now take your edible icing sheet, this is
really thin icing that has been printed with

food colouring, And slide it along the edge
of the counter to loosen it from the backing
and then very gently start to peel it off.

Use scissors to trim the excess white, then
carefully peel off the rest of the plastic.

Now I'll put this printout design on the howtocookthat.net
website, most cake decorating stores can print

your designs for you if not there are places
online that will print it on edible icing.

Lining it up with the top of the cake and
add it to the side and gently press it on.

Line up the next icing sheet and overlap it
slightly.

Now if you very slightly dampen it, it will
stick to itself.
But you don't want to make it too wet.

Then add a strip of black fondant all the
way round the base of the cake.

Carefully lift the cake and place it onto
the record player, now this is why you needed

the hole in the middle of the cake board so
that it can sit over the centre there.

To make your core cannon or the little ship
that shoots down the bottom roll out some
green fondant and cut around it.

Take out the little corners and use your knife
the straighten up the edges.

Now cut a rectangle of black fondant and add
it to the base This is just going to lift
it a bit higher.
Then place that just in front of the cake.

Find the centre of the top of the cake You
should definitely use a ruler to get this
right spot.

Then push the alien lollipop down into the
top.

Now you have a geeky looking space invaders
cake and everyone will wonder why it's on
a record player.

Turn it on and you'll see the top alien animate
but the other aliens are just a blur.
This is where the magic happens.

Look at the cake with a camera and turn the
shutter speed up to 1/500th of a second or
faster.

And all of a sudden the blur turns into animated
little aliens going across your cake.
So cool.

This works a bit like a zoetrope but we are
using the speed of the record player, the

exact spacing of the aliens and the shutter
speed on the camera to get this effect.
This is a cake a true geek they will love.

If you like the effect but want something
other than space invaders cover the cake in
some bright fondant and add decorations.

As I was saying before the spacing is really
important.

Now I've made up some templates or spacing
guides for you just print them out wrap them

around the cake and use that to space your
decorations in the right places.
Then take the paper off.

Turn the record player on and the decorations
will dance around the cake.

Different spacing will make it appear like
they are going forwards or backwards around
the cake.

But as long as you keep them evenly spaced
you can play around with turning them as they

go around the cake, pushing them into the
cake like these yellow ones - just make sure

they complete their movement in one turn of
the cake.

These cake are so much fun and then of course
they taste amazing too with fresh berries,
cream and white chocolate ganache.

Subscribe to How To Cook That for more crazy
sweet creations
Click here for the recipe and the printouts,
here to see all my other cake videos,
here for last weeks raspberry inside dessert
and here for my youtube channel.

Have a great week and I'll see you all on
Friday.
